articles.headline: Gunmen Kill 60 at Concert Hall Outside Moscow, Russian Authorities Say
articles.snippet: The Islamic State claimed the attack, the deadliest in the Moscow region in more than a decade.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State claimed the attack, the deadliest in the Moscow region in more than a decade.
articles.lead_paragraph: Several camouflage-clad gunmen opened fire at a popular concert venue on the outskirts of Moscow on Friday night, killing about 60 people and wounding more than 100, Russian authorities said, making it the deadliest attack in the capital region in more than a decade.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins, Ivan Nechepurenko, Aric Toler and Anton Troianovski

articles.headline: U.S. Call for Gaza Cease-Fire Runs Into Russia-China Veto at U.N.
articles.snippet: The American draft resolution before the Security Council did not go far enough to end the Israel-Hamas war, Russia and China said, after the United States had vetoed three earlier resolutions.
articles.abstract: The American draft resolution before the Security Council did not go far enough to end the Israel-Hamas war, Russia and China said, after the United States had vetoed three earlier resolutions.
articles.lead_paragraph: A U.S. bid to have the U.N. Security Council call for “an immediate and sustained cease-fire” in the Gaza Strip failed on Friday, after Russia and China vetoed the American resolution that included some of Washington’s strongest language since the start of the war.
articles.byline: By Alan Yuhas, Michael Crowley and Thomas Fuller

articles.headline: First He Came for Cancel Culture. Now He Wants to Cancel Smartphones
articles.snippet: The N.Y.U. professor Jonathan Haidt became a favorite in Silicon Valley for his work on what he called the “coddling” of young people. Now, he has an idea for fixing Gen Z.
articles.abstract: The N.Y.U. professor Jonathan Haidt became a favorite in Silicon Valley for his work on what he called the “coddling” of young people. Now, he has an idea for fixing Gen Z.
articles.lead_paragraph: When James Comey became head of the F.B.I. in 2013, he sent reading recommendations to his staff, including “Letter From Birmingham Jail” by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., “Lean In” by Sheryl Sandberg and “The Righteous Mind” by a professor at New York University’s business school, Jonathan Haidt.

articles.headline: The State Had at Least $52,000 of Her Money. Why Couldn’t She Get It Back?
articles.snippet: A financial firm told an account owner that it had turned over her money to the state. When she filed a claim, something strange happened.
articles.abstract: A financial firm told an account owner that it had turned over her money to the state. When she filed a claim, something strange happened.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early in 2022, Sarah F. Cox got wind that someone named Connie was looking for her. The stranger wanted to reunite Ms. Cox with some lost money under her name that the State of New York was holding.

articles.headline: Catherine’s Cancer Disclosure Shows Her Lessons From Previous Media Ordeals
articles.snippet: “They know they can’t control the online world,” one expert on the royal family said about the recent spate of revelations about the health of Catherine and King Charles III.
articles.abstract: “They know they can’t control the online world,” one expert on the royal family said about the recent spate of revelations about the health of Catherine and King Charles III.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than two months, Catherine, Princess of Wales, had lost control of her story to a spiral of wild, baseless online rumors. On Friday evening, with a stark two-minute, 13-second video, she set out to reclaim it.

articles.headline: Russia Arrests 4 Suspects in Moscow Attack as Death Toll Climbs to 133
articles.snippet: As the Islamic State claimed responsibility, President Vladimir V. Putin vowed to “identify and punish” those responsible and tried to implicate Ukraine.
articles.abstract: As the Islamic State claimed responsibility, President Vladimir V. Putin vowed to “identify and punish” those responsible and tried to implicate Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Russian authorities said on Saturday that they had arrested the four individuals suspected of setting a suburban Moscow concert on fire and killing at least 133 people, one of the worst terrorist attacks to jolt Russia in President Vladimir V. Putin’s nearly quarter century in power.
articles.byline: By Paul Sonne and Ivan Nechepurenko

articles.headline: The Brutality of Sugar: Debt, Child Marriage and Hysterectomies
articles.snippet: An investigation into the sugar-cane industry in the Indian state of Maharashtra found workers ensnared by debt and pushed into child marriages and unnecessary hysterectomies.
articles.abstract: An investigation into the sugar-cane industry in the Indian state of Maharashtra found workers ensnared by debt and pushed into child marriages and unnecessary hysterectomies.
articles.lead_paragraph: The two soft-drink makers have helped turn the state of Maharashtra into a sugar-producing powerhouse. But a New York Times and Fuller Project investigation has found that these brands have also profited from a brutal system of labor that exploits children and leads to the unnecessary sterilization of working-age women.
articles.byline: By Megha Rajagopalan, Qadri Inzamam and Saumya Khandelwal

articles.headline: The Man Who Helped Redefine Campus Antisemitism
articles.snippet: In government and as an outsider, Kenneth Marcus has tried to douse what he says is rising bias against Jews. Some see a crackdown on pro-Palestinian speech.
articles.abstract: In government and as an outsider, Kenneth Marcus has tried to douse what he says is rising bias against Jews. Some see a crackdown on pro-Palestinian speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the early 2000s, as the uprising known as the second intifada instilled fear in Israelis through a series of suicide bombings, Kenneth Marcus, then an official in the U.S. Department of Education, watched with unease as pro-Palestinian protests shook college campuses.

articles.headline: The Dogs Helping the Covenant Children Find Their Way Back
articles.snippet: To heal after a mass shooting, the Covenant School families have turned to therapy, faith, one another — and a lot of dogs.
articles.abstract: To heal after a mass shooting, the Covenant School families have turned to therapy, faith, one another — and a lot of dogs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Two of April Manning’s children, Mac and Lilah, had just survived the mass shooting at the Covenant School in Nashville. They needed stability and time to grieve.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Erin Schaff

articles.headline: In Hezbollah’s Sights, a Stretch of Northern Israel Becomes a No-Go Zone
articles.snippet: For the few Israelis remaining in the evacuated zone along the northern border with Lebanon, the simmering conflict there has become intensely personal.
articles.abstract: For the few Israelis remaining in the evacuated zone along the northern border with Lebanon, the simmering conflict there has become intensely personal.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than 60,000 Israelis who live far from Gaza but close to the front line of another spiraling conflict have in recent months been ordered from their homes along Israel’s northern border with Lebanon — the first mass evacuation of the area in Israeli history.
articles.byline: By Isabel Kershner and Sergey Ponomarev

articles.headline: How a Pandemic Malaise Is Shaping American Politics
articles.snippet: Four years later, the shadow of the pandemic continues to play a profound role in voters’ pessimism and distrust amid a presidential rematch.
articles.abstract: Four years later, the shadow of the pandemic continues to play a profound role in voters’ pessimism and distrust amid a presidential rematch.
articles.lead_paragraph: In March 2020, when Joseph R. Biden Jr. and Donald J. Trump competed for the White House for the first time, American life became almost unrecognizable. A deadly virus and a public health lockdown remade daily routines with startling speed, leaving little time for the country to prepare.
articles.byline: By Lisa Lerer, Jennifer Medina and Reid J. Epstein

articles.headline: Russia’s Battle With Extremists Has Simmered for Years
articles.snippet: The Islamic State has long threatened to strike Russia for helping the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, stay in control.
articles.abstract: The Islamic State has long threatened to strike Russia for helping the Syrian president, Bashar al-Assad, stay in control.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the past few months, deep in the forbidding deserts of central Syria, Russian forces have quietly joined the Syrian military in intensifying attacks against Islamic State strongholds, including bombing what local news reports called the dens and caves where the extremist fighters hide.

articles.headline: Screams and Blank Stares of Shock: Horror at a Russian Concert
articles.snippet: The violent attack on Moscow’s outskirts on Friday was a scene of chaos and terror. “You’re just running to figure out where else to run,” one attendee said.
articles.abstract: The violent attack on Moscow’s outskirts on Friday was a scene of chaos and terror. “You’re just running to figure out where else to run,” one attendee said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Once they heard the shots ring out on Friday night at Crocus City Hall, Efim Fidrya and his wife ran down to the building’s basement and hid with three others in a bathroom.
articles.byline: By Valerie Hopkins and Alina Lobzina

articles.headline: Germany’s Solar Panel Industry, Once a Leader, Is Getting Squeezed
articles.snippet: Domestic manufacturers are caught between China’s low prices and U.S. protectionist policies, even as demand increases.
articles.abstract: Domestic manufacturers are caught between China’s low prices and U.S. protectionist policies, even as demand increases.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before China came to dominate the solar panel industry, Germany led the way. It was the world’s largest producer of solar panels, with several start-ups clustered in the former East Germany, until about a decade ago when China ramped up production and undercut just about everyone on price.

articles.headline: Has China Lost Its Taste for the iPhone?
articles.snippet: Apple has deep ties in the country, its second-largest market. But there are signs that Chinese consumers are becoming a harder sell.
articles.abstract: Apple has deep ties in the country, its second-largest market. But there are signs that Chinese consumers are becoming a harder sell.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, Apple dominated the market for high-end smartphones in China. No other company made a device that could compete with the iPhone’s performance — or its position as a status object in the eyes of wealthy, cosmopolitan shoppers.
articles.byline: By Meaghan Tobin, Alexandra Stevenson and Tripp Mickle

articles.headline: ‘Yo Soy la Mamá’: A Migrant Mother’s Struggle to Get Back Her Son
articles.snippet: She came to the United States fleeing her abuser. When child welfare got involved, she risked losing her son forever.
articles.abstract: She came to the United States fleeing her abuser. When child welfare got involved, she risked losing her son forever.
articles.lead_paragraph: Over the final four months of 2021, Olga, a Honduran immigrant in Hollywood, Fla., grew increasingly panicked. She could not find her 5-year-old son, Ricardo. After she’d fled her homeland to escape her abusive husband, the man also migrated, disappeared with the boy and broke off contact.

articles.headline: E.U. Takes Aim at Alphabet, Apple and Meta in Wide-Ranging Investigations
articles.snippet: The inquiries signal the bloc’s intention to tightly enforce sweeping new competition rules that took effect this month.
articles.abstract: The inquiries signal the bloc’s intention to tightly enforce sweeping new competition rules that took effect this month.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alphabet, Apple and Meta were told by European Union regulators on Monday that they were under investigation for a range of potential violations of the region’s new competition law.
articles.byline: By Adam Satariano and Tripp Mickle

articles.headline: Boeing C.E.O. to Step Down in Major Reshuffle at Embattled Plane Maker
articles.snippet: The company’s chief executive, Dave Calhoun, said he would leave at the end of the year. Stan Deal, Boeing’s head of commercial planes, departed immediately.
articles.abstract: The company’s chief executive, Dave Calhoun, said he would leave at the end of the year. Stan Deal, Boeing’s head of commercial planes, departed immediately.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing abruptly said on Monday that it was overhauling its leadership amid its most significant safety crisis in years, announcing sweeping changes that included the departure of its chief executive, Dave Calhoun, at the end of the year.
articles.byline: By Sydney Ember and Niraj Chokshi

articles.headline: Inside a C.E.O.’s Bold Claims About Her Hot Fintech Start-Up
articles.snippet: Amira Yahyaoui, a human rights activist, promoted the success of her student aid start-up, Mos. Some of her statements do not add up, according to internal data and people familiar with the company.
articles.abstract: Amira Yahyaoui, a human rights activist, promoted the success of her student aid start-up, Mos. Some of her statements do not add up, according to internal data and people familiar with the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a Tunisian human rights activist in the 2000s, Amira Yahyaoui staged protests and blogged about government corruption. In interviews, she described being beaten by the police. When she was 18, she said, she was kidnapped from the street, dropped off at the Algerian border and placed in exile for several years.
